dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 3337 IH: Fuels Parity Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mrs. Miller-Meeks (for herself, Mr. Hunt, Mrs. Bice, Ms. Budzinski, and Mr. Sorensen) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Clean Air Act to eliminate the renewable fuel standard advanced biofuel corn starch prohibition, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Fuels Parity Act.

section.header: Eliminating renewable fuel standard advanced biofuel corn starch prohibition

subsection.text: Section 211(o)(1)(B) of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7545(o)(1)(B)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (i), by striking , other than ethanol derived from corn starch,; and
in subclause (ii)(II), by striking (other than corn starch) and inserting , including corn starch.

subsection.text: Section 211(o)(1) of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7545(o)(1)) is amended by striking subparagraph (F) (relating to the definition of conventional biofuel).
The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall apply beginning with the first calendar year that begins after the date of enactment of this Act.

section.header: Greenhouse gas emissions from corn-based ethanol and biomass-based diesel

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b), not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, and every 5 years thereafter, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (in this section referred to as the Administrator) shall update the methodology used by the Environmental Protection Agency in lifecycle analyses with respect to—

paragraph.text: greenhouse gas emissions that result from ethanol derived from corn starch; and
greenhouse gas emissions that result from biomass-based diesel (as defined in section 211(o)(1)(D) of the Clean Air Act (42 U.S.C. 7545(o)(1)(D)).

In carrying out the first update required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall adopt the most recent Greenhouse Gases, Regulated Emissions, and Energy Use in Transportation model (commonly referred to as the GREET model) developed by Argonne National Laboratory.
In carrying out the second and each subsequent update required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall—

subparagraph.text: as necessary, adopt, review, or update a methodology determined to be appropriate by the Administrator; or
adopt the methodology described in paragraph (1).
